item.title: Php Version Switcher: The Structure
item.description: This article is part of my #100DaysOfCode and #100DaysOfBlogging challenge. R1D10 This is part three of a series of articles about the PHP Version Switcher. Part One: Php Version Switcher: PowerShell Module Part Two: Php Version Switcher: PowerShell Naming Convention Today I will talk about the structural concept of the PHP Version Switcher. On Windows you need to add the path of your PHP location to the system environment variable PATH.

item.title: Php Version Switcher: PowerShell Naming Convention
item.description: This article is part of my #100DaysOfCode and #100DaysOfBlogging challenge. R1D9 This is part three of a series of articles about the PHP Version Switcher. Part One: Php Version Switcher: PowerShell Module Yesterday I started off, moving for my PHP version switcher to a new home by creating a PowerShell module. Whilst the import of the module and invocation of the function worked, the Import-Module throw a warning:

item.title: Php Version Switcher: PowerShell Module
item.description: This article is part of my #100DaysOfCode and #100DaysOfBlogging challenge. R1D8 Most of our costumers provide Windows Servers for the PHP applications we implement and maintain for them. Although it has become much easier to get a PHP running under Windows than ten years ago, it’s still not the choice environment for a typical PHP web application. Last year a co-worker and I discussed the possibility of providing each project with a Vagrant box for development purposes that runs a comparable setup as the production environment.
